data.title: Pronunciation: Poseidon
data.meta_description:
Dear participants,
 
How do you pronounce Poseidon? Could anyone write back to me using fonetics to pronounce Poseidon correctly?
 
Best regards,
 
Antonio
data.text:
antonioperestrelo said:

Dear participants,

How do you pronounce Poseidon? Could anyone write back to me using fonetics to pronounce Poseidon correctly?

Best regards,

Antonio

Po: pronounce the "o" like the "a" in "another"

sei: rhymes with "tie," "my," and "high"

don: pronounce the "on" as in "button"

So it's something like PUH-SIE-DIN

Emphasis on the second syllable

I hope that helps.

antonioperestrelo said:

Dear participants,

How do you pronounce Poseidon? Could anyone write back to me using fonetics to pronounce Poseidon correctly?

Best regards,

Antonio

I pronounce it like

"poss" rhymes with "boss" "toss" "moss"

"eye" like what you see with or "I" as in "I am"

"don" as in "London".

Stress is on the "eye" syllable.

Edit - Elroy is right that the vowel of the "poss" is a bit more like "a" or "another" because it hasn't got the stress. So it is like the "poss" of "possess".

timpeac said:

I pronounce it like

"poss" rhymes with "boss" "toss" "mos"

"eye" like what you see with or "I" as in "I am"

"don" as in "London".

Stress is on the "eye" syllable.

Interesting - to me the first "o" is definitely a schwa sound.

Continuing the survey of the British Isles, I'm not certain how timpeac pronounces London, so I can't be sure if I agree - my Poseidon is pretty close to P'side'n - with two schwas.

panjandrum said:

Continuing the survey of the British Isles, I'm not certain how timpeac pronounces London, so I can't be sure if I agree - my Poseidon is pretty close to P'side'n - with two schwas.

Yes, that's what I was hoping t' c'nvey.

timpeac said:

I pronounce it like the second o in Ashton.

Would that be Ashton-under-Lyne or Ashton in Northhamptonshire?

Seems daft, but it's a serious question.

I pronounce the second o in poseidon like the o in Ashton-under-Lyne.

I pronounce the second o on London like the o in Ashton (and like the first o in London).

panjandrum said:

Would that be Ashton-under-Lyne or Ashton in Northhamptonshire?

Seems daft, but it's a serious question.

I pronounce the second o in posiedon like the o in Ashton-under-Lyne.

I pronounce the second o on London like the o in Ashton (and like the first o in London).

I don't know I made it up - sorry I was being facetious. I pronounce it like a schwa, so whichever one has the schwa!!
